conclusion: I'll analyze this refraction problem step by step to determine whether point O₁ is to the right of point O.
The solid horizontal line represents the boundary between air (above) and water (below).
A beam of blue light travels from point A in air, hits the boundary at point O₁, then travels through water to point B.
Point O is defined as the intersection of line AB with the boundary.
We need to determine if O₁ is to the right of O.
When light passes from air to water, the light ray bends toward the normal due to refraction (Snell's Law).
This occurs because light travels slower in water than in air.
The refraction depends on the refractive indices of the two media.
The dashed line shows what would happen if light traveled in a straight line (without refraction).
Point O is where this straight line AB crosses the boundary.
The actual path of light is represented by the two red line segments (AO₁ and O₁B).
O₁ is the actual refraction point on the boundary.

premise: The bent path (AO₁B) clearly shows O₁ is to the right of O.
conclusion: O₁ is to the right of O.
When light travels from air to water, it bends toward the normal (the vertical dashed line).

premise: This bending means the light must hit the boundary at a point (O₁) that is different from where a straight line (AB) would cross the boundary (O).
Since the light bends toward the normal when entering water, the refraction point O₁ must be to the right of O.
conclusion: O₁ is to the right of O.

premise: This is consistent with what we see in the second image, where O₁ is clearly positioned to the right of O along the boundary.
conclusion: O₁ is to the right of O.
